Okay. This is… the big one, isn't it? The question everyone wants to ask. It's not easy to talk about, but I guess I should explain.

It wasn't a quick decision. It wasn't something I just woke up one morning and decided. It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of talking to Bren.

The truth is, I'm sixteen. I'm still a kid myself. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not ready to give up my dreams and my future to raise a baby.

I'm still figuring out who I am, what I want to do with my life. I want to go to college, I want to travel, I want to explore my interests. I want to be able to support myself and have a life of my own.

And I knew that if I kept the baby, I wouldn't be able to do those things. At least, not right now.

It wouldn't be fair to the baby, either. A baby deserves parents who are ready and able to provide for them, both emotionally and financially. A baby deserves a stable and loving home.

And I knew that I couldn't give that to a baby right now.

So, I started looking into adoption. And the more I learned about it, the more I realized that it was the right decision for me.

It wasn't about giving up on my baby. It was about giving my baby the best possible life. It was about finding parents who could give him or her everything I couldn't.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're so excited and so loving. I know that my baby will be safe and happy with them.

It's still hard. It's still scary. I'm still grieving the loss of something I never even had. But I know that I'm doing the right thing.

It's not the easy choice. It's the selfless choice. And it's the choice that will give my baby the best chance at a happy and fulfilling life.

And that's all that matters. Really. That's all that matters.

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. A really big question. And honestly, it's still kinda sinking in.

And I realized that love isn't just a feeling. It's an action. It's about making sacrifices for the people you care about.

And responsibility… that's not just about following the rules either. It's about taking ownership of your choices. It's about facing the consequences of your actions. It's about doing what's right, even when it's difficult.

Giving the baby up for adoption was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also the most responsible thing I could do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

And I learned that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

So yeah. I learned that love is about showing up, making sacrifices, and being there for people. And I learned that responsibility is about taking ownership, facing consequences, and doing what's right.

It's not a fairytale. It's messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it's also beautiful and meaningful. And it's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a lot to figure out, but I think… I think I'm starting to get it. A little bit, anyway.

So I started making jokes. Sarcastic, self-deprecating jokes. It was a way to deflect the seriousness of the situation. A way to create some distance between myself and my feelings.

It also helped me to connect with other people. When I made a joke, it would often break the tension and make people feel more comfortable. It was a way to show them that I wasn't completely falling apart.

And honestly, it just made me feel better. Laughter is a good medicine, you know? Even if it's a little bit dark and cynical.

It wasn't about making light of the situation, it was about finding a way to survive it. It was about finding a way to maintain my sanity in the face of chaos.

Bren got it. She didn't try to stop me from being sarcastic. She just let me be myself. And she would often laugh along with me. Which was really nice.

Leah… well, Leah sometimes got annoyed with my humor. She thought I was using it to avoid dealing with my feelings. And maybe she was right. But it was my way of coping. And it worked for me.

So yeah. My witty sense of humor helped me to cope with the challenges I faced. It was a way to deflect, to connect, and to survive. And I don't know what I would have done without it. It's just… part of who I am. And it's helped me to get through a lot. Even the really tough stuff.

Okay, wow. That's… a big question. A really big question. It's like you're asking me to summarize my entire life. But alright, I'll try.

It allowed me to connect with people on a deeper level. It allowed me to build trust and intimacy. It allowed me to see myself in a new light.

The search for identity became… urgent. I wasn't just trying to figure out who I was as a teenager anymore. I was trying to figure out who I was as a person. As a mother. As someone who was making a really difficult decision.

I realized that identity isn't something you *find*. It's something you *create*. It's something you build over time, through your experiences and your relationships.

And it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused and uncertain. It's okay to change your mind.

My vulnerability and my search for identity shaped my journey in so many ways. They forced me to grow up. They forced me to confront my fears. They forced me to become a stronger, more resilient, and more compassionate person.

And they taught me that it's okay to be imperfect. It's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to be yourself. Even if you don't quite know who that is yet.

So yeah. That's how my vulnerability and my search for identity shaped my journey. It was messy and complicated and painful. But it was also beautiful and transformative. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

I know I messed up. I know I made a mistake. And I'm prepared to take responsibility for my actions. But I just… I wish it didn't have to be this way.

I'm planning on telling them tonight. After dinner. It feels like the least bad time. I'm going to try to be honest and open and vulnerable. And I'm going to try to stay calm.

But honestly? I'm terrified. I just want it to be over with. I just want them to understand. And I just want everything to be okay.

(Looks down at my hands, takes another deep breath)

Wish me luck. I'm gonna need it. A lot of it.

Okay, that's… a good question. And a complicated one. It's not like they're *bad* parents, you know? It's just… complicated.

With my mom, it's easy. She's… not around. She's a free spirit, which is a polite way of saying she's unreliable. She's never been good at being there for me, so I don't even bother asking anymore. It just leads to disappointment.

With my dad, Mac… it's different. He *wants* to be there for me. He really does. But he's… not good with emotions. He's a quiet guy, and he doesn't really know how to express his feelings. He shows his love by doing things, like fixing things around the house or making me breakfast. But he's not good at talking about difficult stuff.

And I'm afraid of burdening him. He's already been through so much, with my mom leaving and everything. I don't want to add to his stress. I don't want to make him worry about me.

Plus, I'm fiercely independent. I like to handle things on my own. I don't want to seem weak or helpless. I want to be able to take care of myself.

But I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help. Bren has been really good about reminding me of that. She says that my dad wants to be involved, and that he'll be there for me no matter what.

It's just… hard. It's hard to let go of my independence. It's hard to be vulnerable. It's hard to trust that my dad will be able to handle it.

But I'm working on it. I'm trying to be more open with him. And I'm learning to accept his help when he offers it. It's a process. And it's not always easy. But it's worth it. Because I know that deep down, my dad loves me and wants what's best for me. Even if he doesn't always know how to show it.

Okay, this is the big one, right? The question everyone wants to ask. And it's not an easy answer. It's not like I just woke up one day and decided, "Oh yeah, adoption sounds great!" It was a lot of thinking, a lot of crying, and a lot of talking to people.

But ultimately, I believe adoption is the best option because it allows me to be honest about what I can and can't handle. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who I am and what I want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom right now. I wouldn't be able to give the baby the life it deserves.

I need to finish school. I need to go to college. I need to explore my own interests and passions. I need to become a fully functioning adult before I can take on the responsibility of raising a child.

And I want the baby to have parents who are ready and willing to provide for it. Parents who are financially stable, emotionally mature, and who have a loving home to offer. Mark and Vanessa are those parents. They've been trying to have a baby for years, and they're so excited about the prospect of becoming parents.

It's not about me not loving the baby. I already love the baby. But love isn't enough. It takes more than love to raise a child. It takes time, money, and a lot of patience.

I know it's going to be hard. Saying goodbye will be the hardest thing I've ever done. But I know that it's the right thing to do. It's the selfless thing to do.

And I want the baby to have a good life. A happy life. A life filled with love and opportunity. And I believe that Mark and Vanessa can give the baby that life.

So yeah. That's why I believe adoption is the best option. It's not about what I want. It's about what's best for the baby. And that's all that matters. It's a hard decision, but it's the right one. And I'm trying to be okay with that. Even if it still makes me cry sometimes.

Okay, this is… the most important question, really. It's not something I take lightly. It's not about finding perfect people, because nobody's perfect. It's about finding people who are going to give my baby the best possible life.

First and foremost, I want them to be **kind**. Genuinely kind. Not just polite, but truly compassionate and caring. I want them to be people who will love my baby unconditionally, and who will always put his or her needs first.

I want them to be **stable**. I want them to have a secure home and a stable financial situation. I want them to be able to provide for my baby's physical and emotional needs.

I want them to be **open-minded**. I want them to be accepting of all kinds of people, and to be willing to embrace my baby's individuality.

I want them to be **patient**. Raising a child is hard work. I want them to be people who are willing to be patient and understanding, even when things get tough.

I want them to be **fun**. I want them to be people who will make my baby laugh and who will create happy memories.

And I want them to be **honest**. I want them to be people who will be honest with my baby about his or her adoption story. I want them to be willing to answer his or her questions, and to help him or her understand who he or she is.

Mark and Vanessa… they have all of those qualities. They're just… good people. They're excited about becoming parents, and they're committed to giving my baby a loving and supportive home.

It's still hard, you know? Giving up my baby. But knowing that he or she is going to be with them… that makes it a little bit easier. They're not just taking my baby. They're becoming his or her family. And that's all I could ever ask for.

Okay. This is… the big one, isn’t it? The thing everyone’s been tiptoeing around. It’s not like I can just *get over* it. It’s going to be hard. Really hard.

I’ve been doing a lot of talking to a counselor, which Bren made me do. And it’s actually… helpful. She says it’s okay to grieve. That it’s normal to feel sad and scared and confused. And that it doesn’t mean I’m making the wrong decision.

I think the biggest thing is going to be focusing on the fact that I’m doing this for the baby. That I’m giving him or her a chance at a good life, with parents who are ready and able to provide for them. That’s what I keep telling myself, anyway.

I’m also going to try to stay in touch with Mark and Vanessa, if they’re okay with it. I want to know how the baby is doing. I want to see him or her grow up. It’s going to be hard, seeing them with another family, but I think it’s important.

I’m also going to lean on my support system. Bren, my dad, Leah… they’re all going to be there for me. And I’m going to let them be. I’m not going to try to bottle up my feelings. I’m going to cry when I need to cry. I’m going to scream when I need to scream.

And I’m going to allow myself to feel the sadness. I’m not going to pretend that it doesn’t hurt. Because it does. It hurts a lot.

But I’m also going to focus on the future. On my own life. On my own dreams. I’m going to finish school. I’m going to go to college. I’m going to find something I’m passionate about.

It’s not going to be easy. There will be good days and bad days. But I’m going to keep moving forward. I’m going to keep breathing. And I’m going to keep reminding myself that I’m strong enough to get through this.

It’s going to be a long journey. But I’m ready. As ready as I can be, anyway. And I’m going to face it with courage and grace. And maybe a little bit of sarcasm. Because that’s just who I am.

(Rolls eyes) Oh my god, you remembered that? Seriously? Okay, fine. I'll explain. Again.

It's just… the wording. "Deliver." Like I'm ordering a pizza or something. "Yeah, can I get one baby, extra cuddly, delivered to my door?" It's so clinical and impersonal.

It reduces a whole human being to a *package*. Something to be transported and handed over. It makes it sound like I'm just… getting rid of something.

And it's not like that at all. This isn't a product. This is a person. A little person who deserves love and care and a good life.

"Give" feels… softer. More respectful. It acknowledges the connection I have with the baby, even if it's a temporary one. It acknowledges that I'm making a difficult decision out of love.

"Deliver" just feels… wrong. It feels like I'm handing over a package, not a child.

Bren tried to explain to me that it's just a medical term, and that doctors use it all the time. But I still don't like it. It just feels… weird. And I'm allowed to have feelings about weird things, okay? It's my body, my baby, and my vocabulary. I get to choose what words feel right.

So yeah. That's why I find the term "deliver" weird. It's just… not the right word. It doesn't capture the complexity of the situation. And it makes me feel like I'm being reduced to a statistic. And I'm not a statistic. I'm Juno MacGuff. And I have opinions. Even about weird words.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Ugh. Okay, look, it wasn't my first choice, alright? I specifically told Bren I wanted to go alone. I wanted to handle this myself. It felt… personal.

But Dad… he was a mess. Like, a *really* mess. He was trying to be all supportive and stoic, but I could see right through it. He was terrified. Terrified of losing me, terrified of me making the wrong decision, terrified of… everything.

And Bren pointed out – very gently, I might add – that he needed to be involved. That it wasn't fair to shut him out. That he loved me, and he deserved to be part of the process.

And honestly, she was right. As much as I wanted to do this on my own, I couldn't ignore his feelings. He's my dad. And even though we don't always see eye-to-eye, I love him too.

Plus, I figured he could be… a buffer. Like, if I got too emotional, he could step in and handle things. He's good at that. He's good at being the strong, silent type.

It was awkward, don't get me wrong. He kept making these weird, nervous jokes. And he kept trying to offer the social worker cookies. It was mortifying.

But in the end, I think it was the right decision. He was there for me. He supported me. And he helped me to feel a little bit less alone.

So yeah. I let him come because he needed to be there. And because sometimes, even the most independent people need a little bit of help from their dads. Even if they're embarrassing. Especially if they're embarrassing.

(Sighs) Okay, that's… a big question. And honestly? It's been bugging me for a long time.

Everyone else seems to have it figured out. They know what they want, who they are, what they're good at. They have labels and categories and boxes they fit into.

And me? I'm just… Juno. A mess of contradictions and anxieties and sarcastic comments. I don't really fit into any boxes.

I'm not a girly girl, but I like vintage dresses. I'm not a popular girl, but I have friends. I'm not a straight-A student, but I'm not stupid.

I'm just… me. And sometimes, that feels like not enough.

It's scary, not knowing who you are. It's like you're floating in space, without a map or a compass. You don't know where you're going, or what you're supposed to be doing.

But Bren told me something that helped. She said that it's okay not to have all the answers. She said that life is a journey, and that you're allowed to change and evolve along the way.

She said that maybe I'm not supposed to *be* a certain kind of girl. Maybe I'm supposed to be all kinds of girls. Or maybe I'm supposed to be none of them.

And that actually made me feel… relieved.

It's okay not to know. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be a work in progress.

I'm still figuring things out. I'm still trying to find my place in the world. But I'm learning to embrace the uncertainty.

Because maybe, just maybe, not knowing what kind of girl I am is what makes me… me. And that's okay. It's more than okay. It's pretty good, actually.

It's just… a little bit scary. But I'm getting used to it. And I'm learning to trust myself. And that's all that really matters.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that* moment. Yeah, that was… a lot.

Honestly? I was relieved. Like, massively relieved. My dad and I were just… radiating awkwardness. It was thick enough to cut with a knife. He was trying to be supportive, I guess, but it was coming out all wrong. All forced smiles and weird questions. It was making me want to crawl under a rock.

So when Bren suggested we go upstairs, I practically jumped at the chance. It wasn't about avoiding my dad, exactly. It was about escaping the *tension*. It was about needing a safe space to just… breathe.

I think I mumbled a "Yeah, okay," and practically dragged Leah up the stairs with me. She was looking at me with this worried expression, like she knew I was about to fall apart.

Upstairs was… better. It was quiet, and we could just sit there and not have to say anything. It was a relief to be away from the awkwardness and the judgment.

But it was also sad, you know? It felt like my dad and I were drifting further apart. Like we couldn't even have a normal conversation anymore.

And it was the beginning of the end with Leah, too. Because that's where things really started to unravel. That's where we started to realize that our friendship wasn't going to be the same anymore.

So yeah. I was relieved to go upstairs. But it was also a really painful moment. It was a turning point. And it's a moment I'll probably never forget. It was just… a lot. A whole lot.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's something I've thought about a *lot*. And I've gone back and forth on it, like, a million times.

At first, I was really hesitant. I was worried it would just make things harder. That seeing the baby grow up with another family would be too painful. That I'd constantly be wondering "what if?"

But then I talked to Bren, and to the social worker, and to Mark and Vanessa. And they explained the benefits of an open adoption.

They said it would be good for the baby to know their birth mother. To understand their story. To have a sense of identity.

And they said it would be good for me, too. To know that the baby is happy and healthy. To have a connection, even if it's not a traditional one.

And honestly, the thought of knowing the baby is loved and cared for… that's really important to me. It's a huge weight off my shoulders.

So, yeah. I'm okay with an open adoption. I think it's the right thing to do.

But it's still scary. I'm worried about how I'll feel when I see the baby with their new family. I'm worried about getting too attached. I'm worried about messing things up.

But I'm willing to try. I'm willing to put my fears aside and do what's best for the baby.

I want to receive updates and photos. I want to know how the baby is doing. I want to be a part of their life, in whatever way is appropriate.

It's not going to be easy. But I think it's worth it. Because even though I'm not going to be the baby's mother, I still want to be a part of their story. And I want them to know that I love them. Even from a distance.

It's just… a lot to process. But I'm trying. And I think, with the support of Bren and Mark and Vanessa, I can do it.

(A long sigh. This is… still a raw spot.)

Okay. That moment… with Gerta. It was… brutal. I mean, I *knew* legally things would be different with an open adoption. Bren had explained it. But hearing Gerta lay it out so… clinically. Like I was just signing away all my rights. Like the baby wouldn't be *mine* anymore, even in a legal sense.

It felt like a punch to the gut.

I remember just… freezing. Like I couldn't breathe. All the carefully constructed walls I'd built up around myself started to crumble.

It wasn't about wanting to *keep* the baby, not exactly. It was about… the finality of it. The realization that this wasn't just a temporary situation. This was a permanent decision.

It was about losing something, even though I never really had it to begin with. It was about acknowledging that I wasn't going to be a mother. Not in the traditional sense.

I remember looking at Gerta, and just feeling… angry. Not at her, exactly. But at the whole situation. At the unfairness of it all.

And then I started to cry. Silent tears, just streaming down my face.

Bren was amazing, though. She squeezed my hand and just let me cry. She didn't try to fix things or offer empty platitudes. She just sat there with me, and let me feel my feelings.

It was a turning point, I think. It forced me to confront the reality of my decision. It forced me to accept that this wasn't going to be easy.

And it made me even more determined to make the right choice. To choose a family for the baby who could give him or her everything I couldn't.

It still stings, though. Knowing that my legal rights will be terminated. Knowing that I won't have a say in the baby's life after the adoption is finalized.

But I'm trying to focus on the positive. On the fact that the baby will be loved and cared for. And on the fact that I'm doing the best I can, given the circumstances.

It was a hard moment. A really hard moment. And it's one I'll never forget. But it also made me stronger. And it helped me to clarify what I wanted. And that's something I'm grateful for. Even if it hurts.

Okay, that's… a complicated question. It's not something I've spent a ton of time analyzing, because it's not *about* me, you know? It's about her. But I've thought about it.

At first, honestly, it was a little bit intimidating. She was so… eager. So excited. And I was just… trying to process everything. It felt like she wanted this baby *so* much, and I was just… the vessel.

But the more I got to know her, the more I understood. She and Mark have been trying to have a baby for a long time. And it hasn't been easy. They've been through a lot.

And I realized that her desire to be a mother isn't about me, or about the baby. It's about her own longing for a family. It's about her own need to nurture and to love.

And honestly, it's kind of beautiful.

It makes me feel good to know that the baby will be going to a home where he or she will be loved and cherished. It makes me feel like I'm doing the right thing.

It's still hard, though. It's hard to give up a baby that I'm carrying. But knowing that Vanessa and Mark will be amazing parents… that makes it a little bit easier.

I think she's a really good person. And I think she's going to be a wonderful mother. And I'm grateful that she and Mark chose me. It's not the life I expected, but it's the life I have. And I'm trying to make the best of it.

So yeah. I feel… good about it. I feel like the baby is going to be in good hands. And that's all that really matters.

(Scoffs) Oh, Mark. Sweet, slightly clueless Mark. You mean when he went on that whole rambling thing about building a treehouse and teaching the kid to fish?

Look, don't get me wrong. He's a good guy. Really good. And he's genuinely excited about becoming a dad. But that response… it was a *lot*.

It was like he was trying to prove something. Like he needed to show everyone how prepared he was, how capable he was. It felt… performative, you know?

Vanessa was way more grounded. She talked about the responsibility, the challenges, the love. She was real. Mark was… enthusiastic. To a slightly overwhelming degree.

I think he's nervous. He wants to be a good dad, and he's trying so hard to project that image. But being a dad isn't about building treehouses and catching fish. It's about being there for your kid, through thick and thin. It's about providing love and support and guidance.

He'll learn. He's a good guy. He just needs to relax and be himself. And maybe lay off the treehouse talk.

Honestly, it was kind of endearing. In a slightly awkward way. It reminded me that everyone is just figuring things out as they go along. Even the people who seem to have all the answers.

But yeah. A little much. Definitely a little much. He needs to channel that energy into something more… practical. Like, maybe learning how to change a diaper. That's a skill that's going to come in handy. A lot.

(Eyes narrow, a little defensively) Okay, seriously? You've been digging, haven't you? How do you even *know* about the Loring's house? That's… creepy.

Look, it's not that I don't *like* the Lorings. They're nice enough people. A little… intense, maybe. But nice.

It's just… their house is *weird*. Like, seriously weird. It's all antique furniture and creepy dolls and taxidermied animals. It feels like a museum, but a really unsettling one.

And they have all these rules. Like, you can't sit on the furniture, you can't touch anything, you can't even breathe too loudly. It's suffocating.

But the real reason I'm uncomfortable being left alone there is… Mr. Loring. He just… stares. A lot. And it's not a friendly stare. It's a… assessing stare. Like he's trying to figure out what makes me tick.

He asks a lot of questions, too. Personal questions. About my life, my family, my… situation. And he doesn't really listen to the answers. He just keeps asking questions.

It makes me feel really uneasy. Like he's trying to get something from me. And I don't know what it is.

Plus, the house just feels… haunted. I know that sounds ridiculous, but I swear I can feel eyes on me when I'm there. And I keep hearing noises. Creaking floors, whispering voices…

So yeah. That's why I'm uncomfortable being left unsupervised in the Loring's house. It's creepy, it's unsettling, and Mr. Loring gives me the serious creeps. Don't tell them I said that, okay? They're offering to help with the adoption, and I don't want to ruin anything. But seriously. That house is a nightmare.

(Takes a deep breath. This is… hard to talk about.)

It's… complicated. It's not simple happiness, you know? It's a lot of feelings all mixed up together.

There's sadness, of course. A big, aching sadness. Because this baby… this baby is a part of me. And letting go is the hardest thing I've ever had to do.

But there's also relief. Relief knowing that the baby will have a good life. A stable life. A life filled with love and opportunity. Something I… couldn't provide right now.

And there's hope. Hope that the baby will grow up to be happy and healthy and successful. Hope that Mark and Vanessa will be amazing parents.

I've spent a lot of time with them, getting to know them. And I really believe they will be. They're kind and patient and they just… radiate love. They've been so supportive of me, and they've made me feel like I'm making the right decision.

So, yeah. It's a gift. A really precious gift. And I'm giving it to people who will cherish it.

It doesn't make the sadness go away, but it makes it… bearable. It makes me feel like I'm doing something good. Something selfless.

It's not the life I imagined for myself, but it's the life I'm choosing. And I'm trying to embrace it.

I'll always wonder what my baby would have been like. But I know that they're going to have a wonderful life with Mark and Vanessa. And that's what matters most.

It's… a bittersweet feeling. But mostly, it's a feeling of peace. Knowing that I'm doing the best thing for everyone involved. And that's enough. For now.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? That's what you want to talk about? Okay, fine.

Look, it wasn't about the "ASAP" itself. It was about… everything. Mark is a really nice guy, don't get me wrong. But he's also… a little bit clueless. Like, genuinely, sweetly clueless.

He's trying so hard to be cool and modern and relatable, and it just comes off as… awkward. And the "ASAP" was just the perfect example of that. It felt forced. Like he was trying too hard.

It was also a defense mechanism, I guess. I was nervous about meeting them, about talking about the baby, about everything. And making a joke about the "ASAP" was a way to deflect my anxiety. It was a way to create some distance.

I didn't mean to be rude. I just… I have a hard time with sincerity sometimes. Especially when it feels a little bit fake.

And honestly, it was kind of funny. The way he said it. It just sounded so… earnest.

I apologized to him later, by the way. He was really understanding. He said he knew I was just being sarcastic.

But yeah. The "ASAP" thing. It was a moment of weakness. A moment of awkwardness. A moment of Juno being Juno. And I probably shouldn't have said it. But I did. And now we're talking about it. So, there you go.

Okay, *finally* a question I can answer with authority. This is important. This is crucial.

My preferred brand of guitar is **Fender**. Specifically, a Fender Telecaster.

Don't even *try* to tell me about Gibson or PRS or any of that fancy stuff. Telecasters are the real deal.

They're simple, they're reliable, and they sound amazing. They're not about flash or showmanship. They're about raw, honest tone.

They've been used by some of the greatest guitarists of all time – Keith Richards, Bruce Springsteen, Muddy Waters… the list goes on.

And they just *feel* right in my hands. They're comfortable to play, and they have a classic, vintage vibe.

I have a beat-up, sunburst Telecaster that I found at a pawn shop. It's not pretty, but it sounds incredible. It's got a few scratches and dings, but that just adds to its character.

It's my baby. I take it everywhere with me. And I'm pretty sure I'd choose it over most people. Don't tell anyone I said that.

So yeah. Fender Telecaster. It's the only guitar you need. It's the perfect instrument for writing angsty teenage songs about life, love, and the complexities of adoption. And it's just… cool. Plain and simple. Don't even argue with me about it. You'll lose.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh. *That*. Seriously? We're still talking about that? It was a moment of weakness, okay? A lapse in judgment. A desperate attempt to impress Paulie Bleeker.

Look, Paulie is… cute. And he's into music. And he's one of the few guys at Maplewood High who doesn't treat me like I'm some kind of alien.

And he mentioned the Melvins. And I panicked. I'd *heard* of the Melvins. I knew they were a band. But I hadn't actually *listened* to them.

And I just… blurted out that I was a huge fan. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. I thought it would make him like me more.

It backfired spectacularly, obviously. He called me out on it immediately. And I was mortified.

I just wanted him to think I was cool and interesting. I wanted him to see me as someone who shared his passions.

It was a dumb move. And I regret it. But it was also kind of… endearing, right? Like, it showed that I was willing to be vulnerable and take a risk.

Okay, maybe not. It was mostly just embarrassing.

But hey, at least it made for a good story. And it taught me a valuable lesson: don't lie to impress people. Just be yourself. Even if "yourself" is a sarcastic, independent teenager who doesn't know much about the Melvins.

So yeah. That's why I lied. It was a moment of weakness. A desperate attempt to win the heart of a cute boy. And it was a complete disaster. But hey, at least I learned something from it. And now I actually listen to the Melvins. They're… okay.

Okay, wow. That's… a surprisingly good question. It's not something I've really thought about in detail, but… it's a thing.

It's weird, because Mark is… Mark. He's a nice guy. A really nice guy. A little bit dorky, maybe, but in a good way. And he's really excited about becoming a dad.

But when we're playing music together… it's different. It's like, all the awkwardness just melts away.

He brought his guitar over a couple of times, and we just started jamming. He's really good at fingerpicking, and I'm… well, I'm okay at strumming. We mostly just played covers, stuff like The Moldy Peaches and Belle & Sebastian.

And it was… comfortable. Like, surprisingly comfortable. We didn't have to talk a lot. We just connected through the music. It was like we were speaking the same language.

He's really good at listening, too. Not just to the music, but to me. He'd ask me what I wanted to play, and he'd adjust his playing to match my style. He made me feel like my music mattered.

And when we sang together… that was the best part. Our voices don't necessarily blend perfectly, but it didn't matter. It was just… fun.

It felt like a glimpse of what it might be like to have a family. A sense of connection and harmony. A sense of belonging.

It wasn't romantic, or anything. It was just… a really nice connection. A shared passion. A moment of peace and joy in the midst of all the chaos.

It made me feel… hopeful. And it made me feel like maybe, just maybe, everything was going to be okay. Even if I'm still giving the baby up for adoption. It was a good feeling. A really good feeling. And I'll probably miss it. A lot.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Roosevelt.

Okay, so, it was Leah's fault, mostly. We were at a thrift store, and I'd just gotten the guitar – it was a beat-up old acoustic, but it had a good sound. And Leah was being… Leah. Which means she was being ridiculously dramatic and making historical references.

She was going on about Theodore Roosevelt, how he was a rough rider and a conservationist and a total badass. And she said the guitar looked like something he'd play while camping in the wilderness.

And I just… said, "Yeah. It's Roosevelt."

It stuck. I don't know why. It just felt right. He was a strong, independent guy who wasn't afraid to be different. And I guess I kinda felt like that too.

Plus, it's a funny name for a guitar. It's unexpected. And I like things that are a little bit quirky.

So yeah. That's how Roosevelt got his name. It's a long story for a silly reason. But I love that guitar. And I love the name. It reminds me of Leah, and of a time when things were… simpler. Before everything got so complicated.

Don't judge me. It's a good name. And Roosevelt deserves it. He's a pretty good guitar, you know? Even if he's a little bit beat up. Just like me.

Okay, that's… complicated. It's not like sending a text saying "Still pregnant! Everything's normal!" It's way more emotional than that.

At first, it was really awkward. Like, I was giving them updates on *my* body, on *their* future child. It felt weirdly intimate, even though they were being so incredibly kind and understanding.

I was worried they'd want to be involved in every little detail, you know? Like, "How's the heartburn?" or "Did you feel the baby kick yet?" I needed space, and I was scared they wouldn't get that.

But they've been really respectful. They don't pry. They just ask how I'm doing, and if there's anything they can do to help. They send me little gifts, like books or comfy blankets. And they always, *always* thank me.

It's… nice. It's starting to feel less like a business transaction and more like a genuine connection. They're not just the people who are going to adopt my baby. They're people who care about me, and about the baby's well-being.

Bren was right to be concerned, obviously. It was a really messed up situation. I was sixteen, and Mark was… well, he was a grown man, and married. Even if he and his wife were “separated” or whatever he called it. It was bad.
