It's not a happy story, but it's my story. And I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to be strong. And I'm learning to trust that everything will be okay. Eventually.

Okay, this is… hard to talk about. It's not something I really admitted to anyone, even Bren.

My biggest fear wasn't about the baby going to a bad home. Mark and Vanessa seemed amazing, and I trusted them. It wasn't about the physical stuff, like the delivery or the paperwork.

My biggest fear was… that I wouldn't be able to let go.

That when the time came to hand the baby over, I would just… fall apart. That I would realize I couldn't live without him or her. That I would regret my decision for the rest of my life.

I kept imagining holding the baby, and then having to give him or her away. And the thought of that just… broke my heart.

I was terrified that I would be selfish. That I would put my own needs and desires above the best interests of the baby.

I knew logically that adoption was the right thing to do. But emotionally, it was a different story. It was so hard to reconcile my head and my heart.

I spent a lot of nights crying myself to sleep, worrying about it. I was scared that I would ruin everything.

Bren helped me a lot with this. She reminded me that it was okay to feel sad and scared. She told me that it didn't make me a bad person. And she helped me to focus on the positive – on the fact that I was giving the baby a chance at a good life.

But even with her support, the fear never really went away. It just… lessened. And I knew that I would have to face it head-on when the time came.

It was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. And I'm still processing it. But I'm learning to live with the sadness and the regret. And I'm learning to trust that I made the right decision. Even if it was the hardest decision of my life.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on my lips) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Bleeker. It's kinda embarrassing, actually.

Okay, so Paulie Bleeker… he was just… there. He was this skater kid at school, kinda quiet, kinda cute, kinda clueless. And he was really into The Smiths. Like, *really* into The Smiths.

I was flipping through a magazine, looking for a name. I wanted something… unique. Something that wasn't too common. And I saw an article about Morrissey, the lead singer of The Smiths. And it mentioned his real last name was James.

And then I just… had a moment. I thought, "Bleeker. That sounds cool." It sounded… artistic. And it reminded me of Paulie, because of The Smiths.

It was totally random. I didn't put a lot of thought into it. I just liked the way it sounded.

And honestly, I thought it was kinda funny. Like, giving my baby's father a name that was inspired by a British singer. It was a little bit ironic.

Paulie didn't even know I named the baby's father after him. I didn't tell him. It was my little secret.

So yeah. That's the story of Bleeker. It's a dumb story, I know. But it's the truth. And it's a reminder of a really weird and complicated time in my life. And honestly? It's kinda grown on me. Bleeker's a good name. Even if it is a little bit ridiculous.

Okay, now *this* is a good question. Finally, something I can talk about with actual enthusiasm.

It wasn't a sudden thing, it kinda… crept up on me. I was listening to a lot of indie stuff, like The Moldy Peaches, and then I stumbled across some Bikini Kill and Sleater-Kinney. And it just… clicked.

It wasn't just the music, though. It was the whole attitude. The DIY ethic. The rebellion. The refusal to conform.

Everything felt so… *real*. Like, these bands weren't trying to be perfect or polished or commercial. They were just being themselves, and they were saying what they believed in.

And it was empowering. Especially as a girl. Seeing women on stage, playing loud, angry music, and taking up space… it was inspiring. It made me feel like I could be anything I wanted to be.

Punk is about questioning everything. About challenging the status quo. About not accepting things as they are. And that resonated with me. I've always been a bit of a rebel, a bit of a nonconformist.

Plus, the fashion is awesome. Ripped jeans, band tees, combat boots… it's comfortable and it's expressive. It's a way to show the world who you are without having to say a word.

It's not just about being angry, though. It's about being passionate. About caring about something. About wanting to make a difference.

So yeah. That's what drew me to punk. It's a community. It's a lifestyle. It's a way of thinking. And it's something that's really helped me to find my voice. It's a little bit messy and chaotic, but that's what I love about it. It's real. And it's honest. And it's loud. And it's perfect.

Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not something I talk about a lot. It still stings, even after all these years.

My mom leaving… it wasn't like a dramatic, screaming match kind of divorce. She just… drifted away. She was always kind of restless, you know? A free spirit. She wanted to "find herself," which basically meant leaving my dad and me to fend for ourselves.

It made me really wary of commitment. Like, why bother getting close to someone if they're just going to leave anyway? It made me build up walls, and keep people at a distance.

It also made me really independent. I learned early on that I couldn't rely on anyone but myself. Which is a good skill to have, I guess, but it also makes it hard to ask for help.

And it definitely affected my relationship with Leah. I was always afraid of losing her, of her drifting away like my mom did. Which, ironically, probably contributed to her eventually pulling away. I was probably too clingy, too demanding.

It made me really cynical about love and relationships. I didn't believe in "happily ever after." I thought it was just a fairy tale.

But then… things started to change. I realized that my mom's choices were about her, not about me. And I learned that not all relationships are doomed to fail.

Bren showed me what a healthy, loving relationship looks like. She and my dad have their issues, but they always communicate and support each other.

And even though my relationship with Leah is complicated right now, I still care about her. And I'm learning to let go of my fears and to trust that our friendship can survive, even if it looks different than it used to.

So yeah. My parents' divorce definitely impacted my relationships. It made me cautious and independent and cynical. But it also taught me the importance of communication, trust, and forgiveness. And it's helped me to appreciate the good relationships I do have. It's still something I'm working through, though. It's not easy. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

(Scoffs) Special? Unique? That's a big word. My life is mostly just… messy.

But okay, if I had to think about it… I guess what makes my story different is that it's not a typical tragedy. It's not a story about a girl who made a "wrong" choice and is now paying the price.

It's a story about a girl who made a *difficult* choice. A choice that was right for her, and right for the baby. And it's a story about finding strength and resilience in the face of adversity.

A lot of people would have seen this as a disaster. A ruined life. But I didn't let it ruin me. I took control of the situation, and I made the best of it.

And I think that's what makes my story special. It's a story about agency. About taking responsibility for your own life. About making your own decisions, even when they're hard.

It's also a story about the importance of family. Not just the family you're born with, but the family you choose. Bren and my dad have been incredible. And Mark and Vanessa… they're going to be amazing parents.

And it's a story about hope. Even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. And I think that's a message that a lot of people can relate to.

So yeah. Maybe my story is special because it's honest. It's messy. It's complicated. And it's real. It's not a fairytale. It's just… life. And I think that's enough.

Plus, I have a pretty good soundtrack. That definitely adds to the uniqueness factor. Just sayin'.

Okay, this is important. Good friends are… essential. Especially right now. I've learned that the hard way.

First, I value **honesty**. I need someone who's going to tell me the truth, even when it's not what I want to hear. I don't need someone who's going to sugarcoat things or lie to me to make me feel better. I need someone who's real.

Second, I value **loyalty**. I need someone who's going to have my back, no matter what. Someone who's going to stand up for me when I'm being attacked, and who's going to be there for me when I'm going through a tough time.

Third, I value **a good sense of humor**. Life is too short to be serious all the time. I need someone who can make me laugh, even when I'm feeling down. Someone who can appreciate my sarcasm and my weirdness.

Fourth, I value **acceptance**. I need someone who's going to accept me for who I am, flaws and all. Someone who's not going to try to change me or judge me.

And fifth, I value **understanding**. I need someone who's going to try to understand my perspective, even if they don't agree with it. Someone who's going to listen to me without interrupting or offering unsolicited advice.

Basically, I need someone who's going to be a good human being. Someone who's kind, compassionate, and supportive. Someone who's going to be there for me through thick and thin.

It's a lot to ask for, I know. But good friends are worth their weight in gold. And I'm lucky to have a few of them. Even if things are… complicated right now. They're the people who keep me sane. And I don't know what I'd do without them.

Okay, that's… a loaded question. It's definitely shaken things up. It's not like everything stayed the same. Not even close.

With my dad, Mac, it's gotten… closer, I guess. He was definitely shocked at first, but he's been really supportive. He doesn't always understand what I'm going through, but he tries. He makes me pancakes and tells me bad jokes, and just… *is* there. It's nice. It's made me appreciate him more.

Bren, my stepmom, she's been my rock. I already said that, but it's worth repeating. She's been the one I lean on the most. She's the one who helps me navigate the practical stuff, and the emotional stuff. She's just… amazing.

With Leah… that's been the hardest part. We used to be inseparable. But after I told her I was pregnant, things just… changed. She was supportive at first, but then she started to pull away. I think she was scared. Scared of what it meant for our friendship. Scared of what it meant for me. We're talking again now, but it's not the same. It's… awkward.

Some of my other friends have been distant too. I think they don't know what to say, or how to act around me. It's like I've become a different person.

And then there are the people who have been judgmental. The ones who whisper and stare and make me feel like I've done something wrong. Those people I try to avoid.

It's been a really isolating experience, honestly. But it's also made me realize who my true friends are. The ones who stick around, even when things are tough. The ones who love me for who I am, flaws and all.

It's changed my relationships, for sure. Some for the better, some for the worse. But it's also taught me a lot about myself, and about the people in my life. And that's something I'll always be grateful for. Even if it's a little bit painful.

Okay, this is getting philosophical. I'm more of a "live in the moment" kind of person, but alright, I'll try to articulate this.

I think a big part of my worldview is shaped by the fact that I've seen a lot of… messiness. Life isn't always neat and tidy. People aren't always what they seem. And things don't always go according to plan.

Because of that, I'm a pretty big believer in **authenticity**. I think it's important to be true to yourself, even if it means being different or going against the grain. I don't like people who are fake or pretentious. I want to surround myself with people who are real.

I also believe in **compassion**. Everyone is fighting their own battles, and everyone deserves to be treated with kindness and respect. I try to be understanding of others, even when I don't agree with them.

I'm a firm believer in **individual freedom**. I think people should be able to make their own choices, and live their lives the way they want to, as long as they're not hurting anyone else.

I'm also pretty skeptical of authority. I don't automatically trust people just because they're in positions of power. I think it's important to question things and to think for yourself.

And I believe in the power of **human connection**. I think we all need each other. We need friends, family, and community. We need people who will support us, challenge us, and love us for who we are.

I guess you could say I'm a bit of a cynic, but I'm also an optimist at heart. I believe that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope. And I believe that we all have the power to make a difference in the world.

Those are some of the values and beliefs that shape my worldview. They're not always easy to live by, but they're important to me. And they guide my decisions and my actions. They're what make me… me. Even if "me" is a little bit messy and complicated.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I'll tell you. It wasn't easy, picking a name. It felt like such a big decision, you know? Like, this little person is going to have to live with this name for the rest of their life.

I didn't want anything too common. Or too weird. I wanted something that was… just right.

I spent weeks making lists, and asking Bren for suggestions. She had a lot of ideas, but none of them really felt right to me.

Then, one day, I was listening to music – The Moldy Peaches, of course – and I heard the song "Anyone Else But You." And it just… clicked.

I decided to name the baby **Phoenix**.

It's a little bit unconventional, I know. But I love it.

It's a symbol of rebirth and renewal. Of rising from the ashes. And that felt really fitting, given everything that's been going on.

It also felt like a way to acknowledge the difficult journey that led to this point. It's a reminder that even after a loss, there's always hope for a new beginning.

And honestly, it just sounds cool.

Mark and Vanessa loved the name too. They said it felt like a perfect fit for their little one.

So yeah. Phoenix. It's a name that means a lot to me. It's a name that represents hope, and resilience, and the power of new beginnings. And it's a name that I hope will bring my baby a lifetime of happiness.

It was the hardest decision I had to make, honestly. But I think I made the right one. It felt… right. And that's all that matters.

Wow. Okay. That's… a big question. It feels like a whole lifetime crammed into a few months.

I learned… a lot. About myself, and about the world. More than I ever expected to.

I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself independent and resilient, but this was a whole different level. Facing something this huge, making these difficult decisions… it forced me to grow up in a way I never anticipated.

I learned that vulnerability isn't a weakness. It's actually a really powerful thing. Allowing myself to be scared and sad and confused, and letting other people see that… it was terrifying, but it also allowed me to connect with people on a deeper level.

I learned that there's a lot of judgment in the world. And that it's okay to not care what other people think. As long as you're being true to yourself, that's all that matters.

I learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about love and support and being there for each other, no matter what. Bren and my dad were incredible through all of this. And even Leah, eventually, came around.

I learned that there are good people in the world. Mark and Vanessa are amazing. They're going to be wonderful parents. And knowing that the baby is going to a loving home makes everything a little bit easier.

I learned that life is messy and unpredictable. And that you can't always control what happens to you. But you can control how you react to it.

And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. Even when it feels like everything is falling apart, there's always a reason to keep going.

This whole experience changed me. It made me more compassionate, more empathetic, more resilient. It made me realize what's really important in life.

It wasn't what I expected my junior year to look like, not even close. But it was… a valuable lesson. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe a lifetime supply of vintage dresses. But other than that, no. It made me who I am today. And I think, in the end, that's a good thing.

(Long pause. She looks down at her hands, then up again, a little softer than usual.)

That's… a hard question. It's easy to look back and say, "Oh, I should have done this," or "I shouldn't have done that." But honestly? I don't know if I would have changed anything.

Everything happened for a reason, I guess. Even the bad stuff. Even the really, really hard stuff.

If I hadn't gotten pregnant, I wouldn't have met Mark and Vanessa. I wouldn't have learned so much about myself. I wouldn't have grown as a person.

If I hadn't gone through this, I wouldn't have appreciated Bren as much as I do. I wouldn't have realized how strong I am. I wouldn't have learned the importance of honesty and vulnerability.

Maybe I could have been more careful. Maybe I could have talked to someone sooner. Maybe I could have avoided some of the drama with Leah.

But those are just "what ifs." And dwelling on them doesn't do any good.

I made the best decisions I could, given the circumstances. And I'm proud of the choices I made. Even the difficult ones.

So, no. I don't think I would have done anything differently. It was a messy, complicated, heartbreaking, and ultimately transformative experience. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

It made me who I am today. And I'm okay with that. Even if "who I am today" is still a little bit sarcastic and cynical. But also a little bit stronger and a little bit wiser.

And that's all that matters, right? Just… learning and growing and trying to be a good person. And maybe, just maybe, making the world a little bit better along the way.

Okay, disappointment. That's… a constant companion these days, honestly. It feels like I'm constantly having to adjust my expectations. Life rarely goes according to plan, you know? Especially not *my* plan.

My first instinct is to be sarcastic. Like, "Oh, great. Just what I needed." It's a defense mechanism. It's a way of distancing myself from the pain.

But then, after the sarcasm wears off, I usually just feel… sad. And frustrated. And a little bit hopeless.

I used to try to fix things. To make everything go back to the way it was supposed to be. But I've learned that you can't always control things. Sometimes, you just have to accept that things didn't work out the way you wanted them to.

Bren has been really good at teaching me that. She says that disappointment is a natural part of life. And that it's okay to feel sad. But it's also important to learn from your experiences and to move on.

So I try to do that. I try to focus on what I *can* control. And I try to find the silver lining, even if it's just a tiny one.

I also try to distract myself. I listen to music, or watch a movie, or hang out with friends. Anything to take my mind off things.

And sometimes, I just allow myself to wallow for a little while. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to grieve. But you can't stay there forever.

Eventually, you have to pick yourself up and keep going. Even when it's hard. Even when you're disappointed.

So yeah. Sarcasm, sadness, acceptance, distraction, and a little bit of wallowing. That's my strategy for dealing with disappointment. It's not perfect, but it works. Most of the time. And it reminds me that even when things don't go as planned, life goes on. And you can still find happiness, even in the midst of disappointment.

Ugh, don't even get me started on Leah. That was… complicated. It still kinda stings, honestly.

At the beginning, Leah was my *person*. My best friend. We did everything together. We talked about everything. We were inseparable. We were, like, a perfectly calibrated unit of sarcasm and shared weirdness.

But then I got pregnant. And everything changed.

I didn't tell her right away. I was scared. I didn't know how she'd react. And when I finally did, she was… distant. She tried to be supportive, but she just didn't *get* it. She didn't understand why I was choosing adoption. She thought I should have just… gotten rid of it.

And she started hanging out with other people. People who didn't have… complicated lives. People who didn't make her feel uncomfortable.

It felt like she was abandoning me. Like she was ashamed of me.

We had a huge fight at the arcade. I said some things I shouldn't have, and she said some things I didn't want to hear. It was awful.

But then, at the end, she came around. She realized that she had been selfish and judgmental. She apologized for not being there for me. And I apologized for pushing her away.

Our friendship didn't go back to exactly what it was before. It couldn't. We had both changed. But we found a new way to connect. A more mature way.

It wasn't about doing everything together anymore. It was about supporting each other, even when we didn't agree. It was about being there for each other, even when it was difficult.

It was a painful evolution, but it was a necessary one. It taught me a lot about friendship, and about forgiveness. And it taught me that even the strongest friendships can be tested. But if they're worth saving, you have to be willing to fight for them.

So yeah. Our friendship evolved from being a perfectly calibrated unit of sarcasm to something… more real. More complicated. And ultimately, more meaningful. Even if it wasn't always easy.

(Pauses, looks away for a moment, then back with a small smile)

Okay, that's… unexpected. I didn't think anyone would ask that. It wasn't exactly a picnic, you know? Morning sickness, weird cravings, people staring at me… it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows.

But… there *were* moments.

My favorite part? It was feeling the baby kick.

Seriously. It sounds cheesy, I know. But it was… amazing. It was the first time I really felt connected to the baby. It was the first time I realized that this wasn't just some abstract idea, it was a real, living human being.

It was a little flutter at first, like a butterfly flapping its wings. And then it got stronger and stronger. It would kick me when I was listening to music, or when I was talking to Bren. It was like the baby was responding to the world around it.

It was a really powerful feeling. It made me feel… protective. And hopeful. And a little bit scared.

It was also a reminder that I wasn't alone. That even though I was going through this on my own, I had a little companion inside me.

I know I made the right decision giving the baby up for adoption. But I'll never forget those kicks. They were a reminder that even in the midst of chaos and uncertainty, there was something beautiful and miraculous happening.

So yeah. Feeling the baby kick. That was my favorite part. It was a little bit of magic. And I'll cherish that memory forever. It's… a good memory. Even if it's a complicated one.
